data.title: Things to do in Paris: +1300 amazing activities
data.meta_description: Discover the best activities in Paris! Whether you want to have fun with your family, on vacation, during the weekend, or give as a gift, find ideas close to you!
data.text:
Top 40 Things to Do in Paris: Ultimate Travel Guide

Planning on heading to Paris for your next getaway? Forget everything you think you know about the French capital! While the city is true to its reputation in many regards ‚Äì it is indeed an infinitely romantic destination ‚Äì , it has much more to offer than first meets the eye.

We, at Funbooker, have curated a selection of one-of-a-kind experiences that are sure to amaze and delight the most seasoned travelers: from helicopter rides over the City of Lights ‚Äì capturing from a bird‚Äôs-eye view the myriad of architectural gems down below ‚Äì to whimsical and adventurous treasure hunts uncovering the city‚Äôs lesser know marvels and secret spots.

Not to mention vintage car tours roaming the capital‚Äôs picturesque streets. One thing is certain: Paris isn‚Äôt a city to be ‚Äòvisited‚Äô, it is a city to be ‚Äòexperienced‚Äô. Follow the guide!

The Top 20 Must-Visit Attractions in Paris

Afraid of missing out on Paris‚Äôs must-visit attractions? Fear not! Here is your one and only bucket list to visit the French capital. From ancient monuments to modern gems, you‚Äôll find here everything you need to plan your Parisian getaway. Let‚Äôs get cracking, shall we?

The Eiffel Tower

Well‚Ä¶ this first one probably won‚Äôt come as a surprise! Built in the late 19th century by world-renowned engineer Gustave Eiffel to mark a hundred years since the French Revolution, the Eiffel Tower definitely ranks very high on the list of Parisian top tourist attractions.

With a height of 330 meters (1,083 ft), the Eiffel Tower, nestled in the iconic Champ-de-Mars, offers breathtaking views of the French capital. A Champagne Bar on the top floor provides the perfect spot to take in the panorama while sipping on a glass of bubbly.

The Arc de Triomphe

Standing tall on the Place Charles de Gaulle, just a stone‚Äôs throw from the iconic Champs Elys√©es, the Arc de Triomphe is yet another of the city‚Äôs top attractions.

While construction was commissioned by Napoleon Bonaparte in 1806 to celebrate the French military triumphs, completion of the construction works stretched over decades.

By the time the Arc de Triomphe was inaugurated in 1836, Napoleon was long gone from power. Famous for its monumental dimensions and its stunning architecture, the monument is most definitely a must-visit.

We highly recommend visiting the Arc de Triomphe at 6:30 pm so you can catch a glimpse of the rekindling ceremony of the Eternal Flame at the Tomb of the Unknown Soldier.

üëâ Book now

The Louvre

Mona Lisa awaits! Nestled in a former royal residence by the Seine, the Louvre is one of the most visited museums in the world‚Ä¶ and rightly so! The museum is home to collections of over 35,000 masterpieces spread across 9 miles of galleries, stretching from Antiquity to the late 18th century.

Highlights of the visit include Leonardo da Vinci‚Äôs famous Mona Lisa, a selection of ancient sarcophagi ‚Äì as well as an Egyptian mummy ‚Äì , the Winged Victory of Samothrace, the Venus de Milo, Delacroix‚Äôs Liberty Leading the People, G√©ricault‚Äôs Raft of the Medusa‚Ä¶ and of course, the signature glass pyramid!

The Sacr√©-C≈ìur Basilica

Next stop: the Sacr√©-Coeur Basilica! Nestled in the picture-postcard Montmartre district, this iconic sanctuary was built between the late 19th and the early 20th centuries by the Church as an act of atonement in a context of political and military unrest.

With its immaculate fa√ßade and stunning mosaics, the Basilica soon became a symbol of the French capital, epitomizing the city‚Äôs romantic spirit and bohemian flair. Be warned, though: you‚Äôll have to put in some effort and climb the 200 steps leading up to the Basilica to enjoy the view‚Ä¶ (or you can simply take the funicular)!

Notre-Dame of Paris

The muse behind Victor Hugo‚Äôs literary classic may have taken a blow ‚Äì it was severely damaged in a fire in 2019 ‚Äì , but it is still standing! The good news: while the cathedral construction spanned almost 2 centuries, it looks like the renovation works might only take 5 or 6 years! Notre Dame is set to reopen in 2024 or 2025 at the latest‚Ä¶ fingers crossed!

In the meantime, you can still head to the √éle de la Cit√© to admire the cathedral from a distance. Even now, it is still quite mesmerizing.

The Champs-Elys√©es

While the French very much enjoy giving their monuments poetic sobriquets, they were quite straight to the point ‚Äì if not humble ‚Äì with this one and simply nicknamed the Champs Elys√©es ‚Äòthe world‚Äôs most elegant avenue‚Äô!

Spanning 1.25 miles from the Place de la Concorde to the Arc de Triomphe, the Champs Elys√©es are a shopaholic‚Äôs dream come true! Hard to believe that the iconic avenue was initially designed by the famous landscapist Andr√© Le N√¥tre as a quaint and picturesque retreat. Lined with chic boutiques and restaurants, it is quite literally one of the busiest spots in the French capital!

The Palais Royal

A stone‚Äôs throw from the Louvre, the Palais Royal was once the residence of an array of illustrious figures, not least of whom were Cardinal Richelieu, Louis XIII, and Anne of Austria.

Commissioned in 1628, the palace ‚Äì which is surrounded by beautiful gardens ‚Äì is a stunning example of classical architecture. It is now home to the iconic Com√©die-Fran√ßaise, an illustrious theatrical institution. Head for the Court of Honor to have a peek of Buren‚Äôs Columns.

The Luxembourg Gardens

In need of a serene retreat after hours roaming the French capital? Look no further! The Luxembourg Gardens are a Parisian‚Äôs favorite for a leisurely stroll away from the city‚Äôs hustle and bustle. Commissioned in 1612 by the famous regent queen Marie de Medicis, the gardens are an urban oasis featuring traditional French as well as English garden designs. Nestled in the gardens, you‚Äôll find the Luxembourg Palace, home to the French Senate.

The Marais

Head to the vibrant Marais district to discover another side of the French capital! This historic area, renowned for its elegant h√¥tels particuliers, has become quite the bohemian hotspot, brimming with trendy boutiques, restaurants, and art galleries.

It is also the Parisian stronghold of the Jewish and LGBT communities. Highlights include: the stunning Place des Vosges, one of Paris‚Äôs oldest squares; the March√© des Enfants Rouges, Paris‚Äôs oldest covered market; as well as the Picasso and Carnavalet Museums.

The Banks of the Seine

With their emblematic booksellers and quaint caf√©s, the banks of the Seine, listed as a UNESCO World Heritage Site since 1991, are a local‚Äôs go-to for sunny strolls and Sunday picnics.

Spanned by historic bridges ‚Äì the Pont Neuf, the Pont des Arts, the Pont Alexandre III ‚Äì and lined with iconic monuments, the riverside is truly a must-stop for any traveler looking to uncover the allure of the City of Lights.

Pigalle & the Moulin Rouge

Looking to get off the beaten track? Head for the Pigalle district! With its historic cabarets, trendy concert venues, and vibrant nightlife, the area ‚Äì home to the world-famous Moulin Rouge and its iconic French Cancan dancers ‚Äì is definitely worlds apart from the French capital‚Äôs polished and elegant avenues. Be warned, though: the area may not be suited for kids. Often dubbed Paris‚Äôs ‚ÄòRed Light District‚Äô, Pigalle is notorious for its countless sex shops‚Ä¶

The Esplanade of the French National Library

While Paris‚Äôs historic monuments, Haussmannian avenues, and quaint streets may paint the portrait of a city deeply rooted in the past, the French capital is also very much looking to the future.

With its four iconic glass towers, the Esplanade of the Fran√ßois Mitterrand Library ‚Äì named after the French President who led the country throughout the 1980s ‚Äì is a prime example of the French capital‚Äôs modern architectural achievements.

Place Vend√¥me

Nestled in the 1st arrondissement, just steps from the Louvre and the Palais Royal, Place Vend√¥me has become the epicenter of French luxury. Home to exclusive jewelers, the opulent square ‚Äì designed by famous architect Jules Hardouin Mansart in the 17th century and lined with elegant h√¥tels particuliers ‚Äì , also boasts one of Paris‚Äôs most luxurious hotels: the Ritz. Looming over the square, the Vend√¥me Column is a tribute to Napoleon Bonaparte‚Äôs military triumphs.

The Op√©ra Garnier

A stone‚Äôs throw from the bustling Grands Boulevards, the Op√©ra Garnier (often referred to as the Palais Garnier) is a stunning example of neo-baroque architecture. With its grand marble staircase, its gilded statues, and its sumptuous crystal chandelier, the monument ranks high on the list of the French capital‚Äôs must-sees.

Unanimously considered one of the world‚Äôs most beautiful opera houses, it is also famous for its elusive phantom, who inspired Gaston Leroux‚Äôs emblematic novel ‚ÄòThe Phantom of the Opera‚Äô.

The Montparnasse Tower

Nestled in the 15th arrondissement, the Montparnasse Tower is yet another symbol of Parisian modernity.

While this 690-foot-tall tower has now become one of the city‚Äôs most emblematic monuments, it was first met with a certain disapproval ‚Äì if not outright opposition ‚Äì when it was inaugurated in the 1970s, as many Parisians believed its modern aesthetic clashed with the timeless elegance of the French capital.

The Panth√©on

Next stop: the legendary Latin Quarter! The Panth√©on was originally designed as a church dedicated to Paris‚Äôs patron saint ‚Äì Sainte-Genevi√®ve ‚Äì and was later converted during the French Revolution into a mausoleum honoring the ‚ÄòGreat Men‚Äô of the French Nation. Behind its iconic facade blending Classical and Gothic inspirations, you‚Äôll find the resting places of some of the country‚Äôs most illustrious historical figures, among whom are Voltaire, Jean-Jacques Rousseau, Victor Hugo and Marie Curie.

üëâ Book now

The Jardin Des Plantes

In need of a refreshing break after exploring the city from top to bottom? Head to the Jardin des Plantes, in the 5th arrondissement. Designed in the 17th century as a botanical garden for medicinal plants, the Jardin des Plantes has remained a center of learning ever since its creation. It is now home to the Natural History Museum, the fascinating Grand Gallery of Evolution, as well as a series of lush greenhouses showcasing plants from all over the world.

The Trocad√©ro Gardens

Nestled in the 16th arrondissement alongside the River Seine, opposite the Eiffel Tower, the Trocad√©ro Gardens offer breathtaking views of the emblematic Iron Lady (they are the go-to spot for taking postcard-worthy photos of the monument).

While its orderly pathways are a favorite among tourists and locals alike for a lovely stroll away from the city‚Äôs hustle and bustle, the gardens also house several tourist attractions, including the Aquarium de Paris and the Palais de Chaillot.

The Parisian City Hall

Originally built in the 14th century ‚Äì and later rebuilt in the late 19th century ‚Äì Paris City Hall stands as one of the capital‚Äôs most iconic landmarks. Behind its stunning neo-Renaissance facade, the historic monument houses the city institutions and features several exhibition spaces that regularly host retrospectives about the French capital‚Äôs extensive history.

The Tuileries Garden

Ready to step back in time? Head to the Tuileries Garden, the French capital‚Äôs oldest French-style garden, for a journey to 16th-century Paris. Commissioned by Catherine de Medici ‚Äì not to be confused with Marie de Medici, who ordered the construction of the Luxembourg Gardens‚Ä¶ ‚Äì the Tuileries Garden may very well be the most beautiful garden in the City of Lights.

Adorned with sculptures by renowned artists including Rodin and Maillol, the garden is home to two sumptuous, albeit lesser-known, museums: the Mus√©e de l‚ÄôOrangerie and the Mus√©e du Jeu de Paume.

The Top 20 Tourist Activities in Paris

Ready to spice up your getaway to the French capital? At Funbooker, we‚Äôve curated a selection of one-of-a-kind experiences that are sure to sprinkle your Parisian stay with a pinch of adventure. Follow the guide!

üéà Flying Over Paris in a Hot Air Balloon

Ready to discover the City of Light from a whole new perspective? Hop on board a hot air balloon and rise 500 feet above the French capital to enjoy breathtaking views over the city‚Äôs rooftops and iconic monuments ‚Äì among which the Eiffel Tower, the Sacr√© Coeur, the Seine, and the Montparnasse Tower ‚Äì from a bird‚Äôs-eye view!

üç∑ Wine Tasting Experiences

Calling all wine enthusiasts! Whether you‚Äôre a novice looking to dip your toes into the world of wine tasting or a seasoned expert interested in refining your mastery of the French terroirs, we‚Äôve selected the cr√®me de la cr√®me of wine-tasting workshops in Paris. From grape varieties to food and wine pairing, you‚Äôll learn everything there is to know about oenology, guided by a sommelier.

üõ•Ô∏è Embark on a Seine River Cruise

Ahoy! Embark on a sightseeing cruise to sail down the Seine River and the Saint Martin Canal tranquil waters and enjoy panoramic views of the capital‚Äôs most iconic landmarks ‚Äì the Eiffel Tower, the Louvre Museum and more ‚Äì standing along the riverbanks. From amphibious bus adventures to romantic gourmet cruises and ‚ÄòHappy Hour‚Äô cruises, there‚Äôs definitely something for everyone!

üç´ Visiting the Chocolate Museum

Be warned, you may have to pop a button! Paris‚Äôs Chocolate Museum is heaven on earth for gourmets and chocolate lovers (and the devil‚Äôs den for dieters). With delicious tastings, hands-on exhibits, and chocolate-making workshops, the Chocolate Museum invites visitors to find out everything there is to know about chocolate, from chocolate history and ancient rituals to the modern chocolate-making process. In a nutshell: yum!

üß™ Perfume Creation Workshop

Ready to uncover the trade secrets behind French perfume craftsmanship? At Funbooker, we‚Äôve selected the finest workshops in Paris, inviting participants to learn everything there is to know about the elegant art of perfume-making. The best part: you‚Äôll get to take home a handmade fragrance that is uniquely yours!

üîí Putting Your Wits to the Test With an Escape Game in Paris

Ready to put your wits to the test? At Funbooker, we‚Äôve curated a selection of the city‚Äôs best escape games, including some outdoor options that‚Äôll take you on a fun adventure throughout the streets of the French capital. Team up to solve enigmas and collect the clues you‚Äôll need to fulfill your quest. On your marks!

üèõÔ∏è Traveling the Globe at the Quai Branly Museum

Ready to explore continents without even having to leave Paris? A stone‚Äôs throw from the Iron Lady, the Quai Branly Museum is home to collections of over 300,000 ethnic art pieces from arts and civilizations from Africa, Asia, Oceania and the Americas.

If you don‚Äôt have time to visit, we highly recommend walking by, if just to have a peek at the stunning architecture ‚Äì the museum was designed by famous architect Jean Nouvel ‚Äì and have a quick stroll in the lush gardens.

üëâ Book now

üåä Taking a Refreshing Break at Aquaboulevard in Paris

In need of a refreshing break with the family after exploring Paris top to bottom? Head to the 15th arrondissement, where you‚Äôll find Aquaboulevard, Europe‚Äôs largest urban water park. Spread over 7,000 m¬≤, the park includes countless attractions and water activities suited to all ages, including wave pools, slides, a wakebox for indoor water skiing, a lazy river and an artificial sandy beach!

üëâ Book now

üöó Vintage Car Tours in Paris

Looking for a grand romantic gesture to make your Parisian escapade truly memorable? Imagine hopping into a vintage car to take your significant other on a scenic tour through Paris‚Äôs quaint and picturesque streets. You‚Äôll travel back in time and cozy up on the plush seats of a classic French automobile ‚Äì like the emblematic Citro√´n 2CV ‚Äì while discovering the city‚Äôs historic monuments as well as lesser-known marvels and secret spots.

üöÅ Flying Over Paris & Versailles in a Helicopter

Admire Paris‚Äôs emblematic landmarks and Versailles‚Äôs iconic Palace from a whole new perspective! You‚Äôll hop on a helicopter for a 25-minute flight over the French capital and discover some of the city‚Äôs famous monuments from a bird‚Äôs-eye view ‚Äì the Eiffel Tower, the Montparnasse Tower, the Longchamp Racecourse, the Bois de Boulogne and the Trocad√©ro ‚Äì before landing in Versailles for an hour-long break including some refreshments. It‚Äôll be the perfect occasion to chat with your pilot who‚Äôll be happy to teach you one or two things about flying. After an hour, you‚Äôll hop back on the helicopter to fly back to Paris!

üóº Roaming Through Paris on an Electric Quad

Looking for adventure? Gear up and embark on a one-of-a-kind journey through the streets of the French capital! You‚Äôll hop on an electric quad ‚Äì both eco-friendly and easy to maneuver ‚Äì and join your guide in exploring some of Paris‚Äôs top attractions, including the Eiffel Tower, the Champs √âlys√©es, the Arc de Triomphe‚Ä¶ Ready, set, go!

üßÅ Discovering French Gastronomy on a Parisian Food Tour

Attention, food lovers! What better way to discover French gastronomy than by joining a Parisian food tour? At Funbooker, we‚Äôve curated a selection of the most delicious tours in the city. You‚Äôll follow an experienced tour guide through the picture-postcard streets of the French capital, meeting local artisans passionate about sharing their culinary secrets and tasting a selection of exquisite French delicacies.

üéÆ Paris in Virtual Reality

If you believe virtual reality is just for teenage nerds and gaming dorks, think again! At Funbooker, we‚Äôve unearthed the perfect virtual reality activity for curious visitors exploring the French capital: FlyView. You‚Äôll get to choose between four spectacular experiences: flying over Paris with a 360 view from the sky, a virtual reality tour exploring secret and inaccessible spots in the French capital, a virtual reality journey to the heart of Ancient Egypt and a virtual reality tour of Notre-Dame before and after the fire. In a nutshell: it‚Äôs mind-blowing!

ü™∂ Parisian Indoor Skydiving

Ready to get your adrenaline pumping? Experience the exhilaration of free-falling without hopping on a plane! How is it even possible? With a state-of-the-art indoor skydiving simulator: a giant glass tunnel with airflow. The activity is safe and accessible for the whole family! An instructor will take you through the whole process, give you a quick security briefing, help you gear up and teach you how to fly your body.

üç∏ Mixology Classes (Crafting Cocktails)

When exploring the French capital, you‚Äôll soon discover that the French sure know how to indulge! While the country may be the world‚Äôs wine capital, of course, the French have also mastered the delicate art of cocktail-making! Want to uncover the secrets of the best mixologists in Paris? At Funbooker, we‚Äôve selected the cr√®me de la cr√®me of cocktail-making workshops in the French capital. Ready to learn from the master indulgers?

‚ùì Scavenger Hunt Through the Streets of Paris

Tired of traditional, uneventful guided tours? We‚Äôve got you covered! At Funbooker, we‚Äôve curated a selection of the best scavenger hunts in Paris: the perfect activity to unravel the city‚Äôs rich history while having a blast! Solve enigmas, chase clues, and uncover the city‚Äôs secret spots. What better way to keep the whole family entertained while exploring the French capital!

üñºÔ∏è Visiting the Dali Museum in Paris

Fun fact: although Salvador Dali was born and raised in Spain, his journey as an artist ‚Äì much like that of his fellow countryman, Picasso ‚Äì is inextricably tied to France.

Nestled in Montmartre ‚Äì known as the artists‚Äô haven in the French capital ‚Äì the Dali Museum is a tribute to the Spanish artist‚Äôs long and prolific career. Recently renovated, the museum boasts an impressive collection of over 300 masterpieces ‚Äì including paintings, sculptures, engravings, objects of all kinds and furniture.

üëâ Book now

üßë‚Äçüç≥ Parisian Cooking Class

What if you could bring home a delicious selection of secret French recipes? At Funbooker, we‚Äôve curated the best cooking classes in Paris, so you can learn from the city‚Äôs best chefs! Whether you‚Äôre a novice interested in dipping your toes in French gastronomy or a seasoned cook looking to master advanced techniques, there‚Äôs something for everyone. Grab aprons: ready, set, cook!

üêü Exploring the Deep at the Paris Aquarium

Nestled in the Trocad√©ro Gardens, a stone‚Äôs throw from the Eiffel Tower, the Paris Aquarium invites visitors to delve into ocean depths without ever leaving the French capital! Boasting over 10,000 fish, from colorful clown fish to fearsome sharks, the aquarium showcases a diversity of marine habitats, taking visitors on a spectacular journey throughout the world‚Äôs oceans. Entrance tickets grant access to all exhibitions as well as interactive workshops, activities and live shows.

üßë Exploring the City of Sciences & Industry
